{{Infobox company | name = R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company | logo = RRD_official_logo.png | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Public company|Public]] | traded_as = {{NYSE|RRD}}
[[S&P 600|S&P 600 Component]] | industry = Commercial [[printing]], Logistics and Supply Chain, Digital Marketing | foundation = 1864 | location = [[Leo Burnett Building|35 West Wacker Drive]]
[[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois, 60601]]
[[United States]] | key_people = Dan Knotts, CEO | revenue = $6.896 billion USD (2016)http://otp.investis.com/clients/us/rr_donnelley/SEC/sec-show.aspx?Type=page&FilingId=11892516-283236-288394&CIK=0000029669&Index=16000 | num_employees = 60,000 (2017) | homepage = https://www.rrdonnelley.com/ }} '''RR Donnelley''' is a [[Fortune 500]] integrated communications company that provides marketing and business communications, commercial printing, and related services. Its corporate headquarters are located in [[Chicago, Illinois]], United States. == History== R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company was founded in Chicago in 1864 by Richard Robert Donnelley. His son, Reuben H. Donnelley, founded the otherwise unrelated company formerly known as [[R. H. Donnelley]].Donnelley, Gaylord. ''To Be A Good Printer'' (Lakeside Press, 1977) ASIN B000S5KF9I Richard Robert Donnelley established his company in downtown Chicago, which in 1870 became the Lakeside Printing and Publishing Company. The business was destroyed in the [[Great Chicago Fire]] of 1871. After a series of reorganizations and expansions, Donnelley built the [[Lakeside Press Building]] on Plymouth Court, and in 1902 began construction of the [[R.R. Donnelley and Sons Co. Calumet Plant]] on 21st Street and Calumet Avenue. The company aimed to produce books and periodicals with impressive modern design and mass printed commercial and reference materials. Lakeside Press produced [[Encyclopædia Britannica]], ''[[Time Magazine]]'', ''[[Life Magazine]]'', promotional literature for the [[Model T Ford]], catalogs for [[Sears Roebuck]], among others.[http://www.rrdonnelley.com/timeline/index.aspx R.R. Donnelley Timeline] The Press produced high quality collectible editions for the Chicago [[Caxton Club]] and the [[Limited Editions Club]]. Donnelly was the official printer for the 1933-1934 [[Century of Progress|World's Fair, "A Century of Progress]]," which took place on the Lake Michigan lakefront just to the east of the plant. The company designed and printed official tickets, postcards, posters, brochures, and magazines which displayed the company's distinctive modernist design. "https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/webexhibits/PrintingForTheModernAge/PrinterToTheModernistMovement.html Printer to the Modernist Movement: A Century of Progress]" [https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/webexhibits/PrintingForTheModernAge/index.html University of Chicago Library] (Accessed May 2015) The company eventually became a global provider of printing and print-related services.{{sfnb|Davis|1922|p = 25-29}} From 1922-1945, the Director of Design and Typography was [[William A. Kittredge (designer)|William A. Kittredge]],[http://mms.newberry.org/xml/xml_files/kittredge.xml Biography of William A. Kittredge] [http://www.newberry.org/ The Newberry] who commissioned other well-regarded artists and designers, such as [[Rudolph Ruzicka]], [[Edward A. Wilson (illustrator)|Edward A. Wilson]], and [[William Addison Dwiggins|W.A. Dwiggins]].{{sfnb|Hutner|2004| p = [https://books.google.com/books?id=On2cttWtZ9AC&pg=PR37&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false XXXVII]}} RR Donnelley's [[cartography|cartographic]] production facility grew to be one of the largest custom mapmaking companies in the [[United States]]. In the early 1990s, the division successfully integrated routing technology with its digital map databases and launched a separate company, Geosystems, which several years later became [[MapQuest]]. The Calumet Plant, a building which also included company headquarters, was closed in 1993. ==Lakeside Press Apprentice School and labor relations== In 1908 T.E. Donnelley, son of the founder, opened Lakeside Press Apprentice School. Donnelley, a Yale graduate and a trustee of the University of Chicago, felt that the recent revival of the ancient practice of apprenticeship was unsatisfactory because unions dominated the rules. He determined to open a program modeled on the [[Apprenticeship|apprentice training program]] at the Chaix Printing Company in Paris, France, which combined instruction and practical experience. "The whole plant," in the words of one official description, "is the laboratory of the school" {{sfnb|Davis|1922|p = 25-29}} The inscription for the 1913 handbook for apprentices stated that "The employer should realize that engaging an apprentice is a much more important task than hiring a journeyman." {{sfnb|Lakeside Press|1913| p = iii }} A 1933 pamphlet bragged that the apprentices "learn the ancient craft of printing on the finest of modern equipment" and "are imbued with the conviction that the better they do their work, the more they will earn and the higher they will rise.{{sfnb||1933| p = 6-7}} The company was one of many which at the time offered apprenticeship courses of this type, ranging from the [[American Bridge Company]] and the [[American Locomotive Company]] to the [[Winchester Repeating Arms Company]].{{sfnb|Davis|1922|p = 119}} In the early years, ome 90 percent of the company's executives and supervisors were graduates of the Apprentice Training School and were either college graduates who had gone through a training program or had come up through the ranks. The firm’s turnover remained low. As Chicago became home to a northward migration of blacks, the workforce became stratified as non-whites found it hard to attain management positions. Racial tensions in the 1960s further weakened the company's ability to meet technological challenges and global competition. Declining fortunes led to layoffs and contention, and the school closed in 1993.{{sfnb|Reingold|2002| p = 191}} ==The Four American Books Campaign== Donnelley launched a "Four American Books" campaign in 1926 which culminated with their publication in 1930. The aim was to establish that the company's modern commercial machinery could produce illustrated books to rival high-quality presses in Europe and to establish a reputation as a printer of fine trade editions in order to enter the mass-market book industry. The choice of American authors reflected a growing pride in and market for American literature. C. G. Littell, vice president and treasurer, and William A. Kittredge, head of the department of design and typography, organized the campaign.[https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/webexhibits/PrintingForTheModernAge/PromotingTheCraftAmericanBooks.html Promoting the Craft: The Four American Books Campaign] [https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/webexhibits/PrintingForTheModernAge/index.html Printing for the Modern Age: Commerce, Craft, and Culture in the RR Donnelley Archive] (Accessed May 2015). When Kittredge approached [[William Addison Dwiggins]] about illustrating a book for the project, Dwiggins, who was a well-established designer of magazine and newspaper advertisements, replied that he welcomed the chance to "do something besides waste-basket stuff" which would be "promptly thrown away." After he turned down several suggestions, Dwiggins agreed to illustrate the ''Tales'' of [[Edgar Allan Poe]]. The Press considered his fee of $2,000 low for an illustrator of his commercial power.{{sfnb|Benton|2000 | p= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WbpOcowMfCIC&pg=PA131&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false 132]}} Edward A. Wilson illustrated [[Richard Henry Dana, Jr.|Richard Henry Dana]]'s mid-19th century sea-adventure [[Two Years Before the Mast]] and Rudolph Ruzicka [[Henry David Thoreau]]'s [[Walden]].{{sfnb|Benton|2000 | p= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WbpOcowMfCIC&pg=PA131&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false 162]}} The best known of the publications in the series was [[Rockwell Kent]]'s edition of [[Herman Melville]]'s novel, [[Moby-Dick]], which at that point was not yet accepted as an American classic. Kittredge commissioned Kent to perform the design and illustrations in 1926, and the book appeared four years later in a three-volume limited edition of one-thousand copies issued in an aluminum slipcase. Kittredge called it "the greatest book done in this generation" and declared that "we will all go jump in the lake" if "it is not the greatest illustrated book ever done in America." {{sfnb|Benton|2000 | p= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WbpOcowMfCIC&pg=PA131&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false 132, 200]}} (In fact, the book is considered one of the finest of the 20th century.{{sfnb|Hutner|2004| p = [https://books.google.com/books?id=On2cttWtZ9AC&pg=PR37&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false XXXVII]}}) [[Random House]] quickly issued a one-volume trade edition, which was also printed by Lakeside Press, bound in black cloth with silver print and decorations.[http://www.fedpo.com/BookDetail.php?bk=232 Moby-Dick] ''First Edition Points'' (accessed February 6, 2015). The book's cover and the first advertisements both featured Kent's name but did not mention Melville's. Kent's design, especially in the [[Modern Library]] edition of 1943, helped the novel to find a wider audience.{{sfnb|Benton|2000 | p= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WbpOcowMfCIC&pg=PA131&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false 105-107]}} Kent's illustrations give the impression of being woodcuts but are in fact ink and wash. Kent counselled Kittredge that the "whole book is a work that should be read slowly, reflectively; the large page and type induce such reading. The character of the type should be homely, rather than refined and elegant, for homeliness flavors every line that Melville wrote." He wrote that he had thought of using a fourteen-point [[Caslon]] type-face, and he did make the pages rather large. The artist considered his illustrations "literary woodcutting, not engraving," and added that the illustrations show the "midnight darkness enveloping human existence, the darkness of the human soul, the abyss, -- such is the mood of Moby-Dick."{{sfnb|Benton|2000 | p= [https://books.google.com/books?id=WbpOcowMfCIC&pg=PA131&dq=Rockwell+Kent+Moby-dick+lakeside&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UFHUVK3lGoWQyAT84YDQCg&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Rockwell%20Kent%20Moby-dick%20lakeside&f=false 105-107]}} In 1992, the [[Library of Congress]] held an exhibition devoted to the Four American Classics series. {{sfnb|Badaracco|1992| p = }} ==Lakeside Press Galleries== in 1929, the company opened the Lakeside Galleries on the eight floor of their newly completed building on 22nd Street, near the shores of Lake Michigan. From 1930 to 1961, when corporate headquarters were moved, the galleries devoted exhibitions to the works of American and European artists and photographers, as well as to typography and book design.University of Chicago Library, "[https://www.lib.uchicago.edu/e/webexhibits/PrintingForTheModernAge/PromotingTheCraftExhibitions.html Printing for the Modern Age]." == Business acquisitions and mergers == Throughout its history, particularly in the 1990s and 2000s, RR Donnelley purchased a number of other companies outright, steadily increasing in size. In February 2004, RR Donnelley [[merger|merged]] with Moore Wallace Inc., keeping the name RR Donnelley as the name of the combined companies. Donnelley went on to purchase OfficeTiger, a major publishing and financial outsourcing company, as well as printing company [[Banta Corporation]] in 2007. In May 2007, RR Donnelley also acquired book and educational materials printer Von Hoffmann (and creative/ pre-press subsidiary Anthology Inc.) from Visant Corporation.{{cite news | last = The Associated Press | title = RR Donnelley to buy Van Hoffmann | url = http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2007/01/03/rr_donnelley__sons_to_buy_van_hoffmann/ | accessdate = 2007-12-29}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} An additional purchase at the beginning of 2007 was Perry Judd's Holdings Inc., a private catalog and magazine printer. At the beginning of 2008, RRD also announced the acquisition of Pro Line Printing, Inc.{{cite news | last = Business Wire | title = RR Donnelley to Acquire Pro Line Printing Inc. | url = https://www.forbes.com/businesswire/feeds/businesswire/2008/02/27/businesswire20080227005540r1.html | accessdate = 2008-02-27 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} As of 2007, RR Donnelley is the world's largest commercial printer.{{cite web | last = RRD Corporate Website | title = Frequently Asked Questions | url = http://www.rrdonnelley.com/wwwRRD/FAQ/Corporate.asp | accessdate = 2007-12-22 }} In 2005 it acquired Hong Kong based Asia Printers Group from [[CVC Capital Partners]].{{cite news|url=https://www.ft.com/content/2d82628e-d5f9-11d9-8040-00000e2511c8|title= RR Donnelley buys Asia Printers |date=6 June 2005|access-date=1 October 2017|work=The Financial Times}} Asia Printers Group consists of South China Printing, which was acquired by Asia Printers Group in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.singtaonewscorp.com/notice/announcement/_2007112114151843919.pdf|title=Joint Announcement|date=25 January 2002|access-date=1 October 2017|publisher=Sing Tao Holdings c/o Global China Technology Group}} In 2006 it acquired [[Canadian Bank Note Company]]'s financial printing business, consisting of documentation for initial public offerings. In 2007, RR Donnelley was also named as an interested party in an attempt to purchase [[Quebecor World]].{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/reuters/071218/business/business_quebecorworld_report_col_1|title=At least four firms eyeing Quebecor World: report|author=Reuters|date=2007-12-18|publisher=''Yahoo! News Canada''|accessdate=2007-12-22}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In May 2009, the company tendered an unsolicited bid to purchase Quebecor World.{{cite news | url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/05/13/donnelley-quebecor-world-takeover.html?ref=rss | work=CBC News | title=RR Donnelley proposes .3 billion US takeover of Quebecor World | date=2009-05-13 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090726050600/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/montreal/story/2009/05/13/donnelley-quebecor-world-takeover.html?ref=rss | archivedate=2009-07-26 | df= }} In July 2008, the company established a multi-year contract with [[F+W Publications Inc.]], which will allow Donnelley to print a large amount of F + W's [[book]] and [[magazine]] publications. The contract is valued at about $80 million.{{cite news | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/business/chicago-rr-donnelley-fw-jul8,0,6578112.story | title=R.R. Donnelley gets $80M contract with F + W | publisher=Chicago Tribune | date=2008-07-08 | accessdate=2008-07-08}}{{dead link|date=April 2017}} In 2010 and 2011, RR Donnelley acquired [[Bowne & Co.]], San Francisco-based Nimblefish Technologies,{{cite news | url=http://www.globenewswire.com/newsroom/news.html?d=209016 | title=RR Donnelley Acquires Nimblefish Technologies to Expand Multi-Channel Marketing Capabilities | publisher=RR Donnelley press release | date=2010-12-14 | accessdate=2012-01-10}} [[Helium.com]],{{cite news | url=http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9O0GCR81.htm | title = RR Donnelley buys Helium.com, terms not disclosed | publisher = Bloomberg Businessweek | date=2011-06-21 | accessdate=2012-01-10}} and Austin-based LibreDigital.{{cite web|url=http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2011/08/17/454114/229752/en/RR-Donnelley-Acquires-LibreDigital-Extends-e-Reader-Services-Into-Book-Magazine-and-Newspaper-Segments.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306140252/https://globenewswire.com/news-release/2011/08/17/454114/229752/en/RR-Donnelley-Acquires-LibreDigital-Extends-e-Reader-Services-Into-Book-Magazine-and-Newspaper-Segments.html |archivedate=2016-03-06 |df= }} During the Labor Day weekend in September 2011, RR Donnelly announced it would close its [[Bloomsburg, Pennsylvania|Bloomsburg]] printing plant where [[Penguin Classics]] and paperbacks in the best-selling Twilight and [[Idiot's Guide]] series were printed. On August 15, 2012, RR Donnelley acquired [[EDGAR Online]].{{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/2031/0001193125-12-357213.pdf |title=EDGAR Online, Form 8-K, Current Report, Filing Date Aug 15, 2012 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =Feb 26, 2013}} In 2013, RR Donnelly acquired [[Consolidated Graphics]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20131026061007/http://www.foliomag.com/2013/rr-donnelley-buy-consolidated-graphics-620m#.UmnEtRCE7XU RR Donnelley to Buy Consolidated Graphics for $620M] In August 2015, the company announced it would spin-off into three different companies. One would keep the name RR Donnelley & Sons whereas the other two would be titled [[LSC Communications]] and Donnelley Financial Solutions.{{cite web|title=R.R. Donnelley (RRD) to Split into 3 Stocks by October, published May 5, 2016|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/joecornell/2016/05/05/r-r-donnelley-rrd-to-split-into-3-stocks-by-october/#6d8307ac656a|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=24 September 2017}} The spin was completed in October 2016. == Lakeside press == '''Lakeside Press''' was a Chicago [[Imprint (trade name)|publishing imprint]] under which the RR Donnelley Company produced fine-quality books as well as mail order catalogs, telephone directories, encyclopedias, and advertising. The Press was best known for its high quality editions for the Chicago [[Caxton Club]] as well as the Lakeside Classics, a series of fine reprints produced annually, at [[Christmas]] time, by RR Donnelley.{{cite web | last = RRD Corporate Website | title = Lakeside Classics | url = http://www.rrdonnelley.com/wwwRRD/AboutUs/LakesideClassics/LakesideClassics.asp | accessdate = 2007-12-22 }} The Lakeside Classics tradition began in 1903 by Thomas E. Donnelley, who was then the company president. The basic format of these books remained essentially the same since inception, as a hardcover, cloth wrapped and gold embossed. Subject matter tended to cover elements of American history. Many early volumes contained speeches and writings of noted Americans, including [[Benjamin Franklin]], whose [[autobiography]] was published as the first Lakeside Classic. ===Lakeside Classics=== [[RR Donnelly#Lakeside Classics|Lakeside Classics]] is a series started in 1903 that reprints neglected classic works. Thomas E. Donnelley, then president of the company, was impressed by a set of seven razors presented to him by one of the company's suppliers, and wanted to create a gift that would similarly represent his own company's product and could not be purchased on the open market. The company did not sell the books to the public, but gave each of the company employees a copy at Christmas, making the series valued collectors items.[http://www.rrdonnelley.com/about/lakeside-classics/ Lakeside Classics] Thomas Donnelley wrote in the introduction to ''[[Autobiography of Benjamin Franklin]]'', the first volume in the series, that "If, in a modest way this volume conveys the idea that machine-made books are not a crime against art, and that books may be plain but good, and good though not costly, its mission has been accomplished." Following volumes featured speeches and writings of noted Americans, then in the 1910s selections turned to first-person narratives of American history, especially those which were rare or out of print. Themes included the Civil War, the Old West, exploration and frontier life. In the 1990s, several changes were introduced. Partly to acknowledge the company's global markets, narratives by Americans abroad were included. An early admirer wrote in 1923 that the printing, binding, and finishings were all done by the apprentice class to "illustrate the ideals of a well-made book," and that "not only are these books well made, but they contain historical works, autobiographies, and early travels unforgettable to him who loves this fair land." He concluded that the series is becoming "an institution near and dear to the collector of books of intrinsic value and beauty." {{sfnb|Bay|1923| p = [https://books.google.com/books?id=UJg8AQAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA100&dq=lakeside+press+history+volume+1&hl=en&sa=X&ei=3p3SVJ_aA8LjsAT_q4G4BA&ved=0CFQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=lakeside%20press%20history%20volume%201&f=false 101]}} Minor design changes were made occasionally and a major redesign every quarter century. In 1995, the date line on the title page was changed from "Christmas" to "December." For the redesign in 2003, [[Bruce Campbell (book designer)|Bruce Campbell]], known for his work on [[The Library of America]], was engaged. Among other changes, the gold-framing on the cover was restored and the typeface was changed from [[Bulmer (typeface)|Bulmer]] to [[Garamond]] Susan Levy [http://www.caxtonclub.org/reading/2012/dec12.pdf The Lakeside Classics: A Christmas Gift that Keeps on Coming] ''The Caxtonian'' 20.12 December 2012. The company did not keep detailed records on how many copies were printed. The preface to the 1935 volume says that the print run for the first volume was 1,500 copies, but no further information was included in later editions. In the 1970s printings were in the tens of thousands. The hardest volume to find is the 1904 ''Inaugural Addresses of the Presidents, Washington to Lincoln''. It is not known whether the run was smaller or whether collectors of Washington and Lincoln have kept them off the market by retaining them. The second scarcest is ''Fruits of Solitude'', which may have been easy to lose because it had the fewest number of pages. The difficulty of finding the volume ''Memorable Speeches'' led one family member to joke that the speeches were so unmemorable that everyone threw them out. The Chicago publisher Reilly & Britton, a Chicago publisher, was given rights to reissue some of the earliest titles as “The Patriotic Classics.” By 2015, the series included 113 volumes. Lakeside Classics were not sold to the public and only made available to RR Donnelley employees, clients and others associated with the company. The week before Christmas, each employee was given one copy of that year's volume. As such, some of the volumes have become scarce, and are in demand on the collectors' market. [[Antiquarian]] bookstores often have a section devoted to Lakeside Classics, and early volumes command large sums from book collectors. ==Publications== * {{cite book |last = Davis |first = Carl Dewitt |year = 1922 |title = A Study of the School for Apprentices of the Lakeside Press |publisher = R. R. Donnelley & sons Company| location = |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xYXPAAAAMAAJ |isbn = |ref = harv}} * {{cite book | author = Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation |title = Official pictures of a Century of Progress exposition. Photographs by Kaufmann & Fabry co., official photographers | location = Chicago | year = 1933 | url = http://century.lib.uchicago.edu/images/century0087.pdf | ref = none}} * {{cite book |last = Donnelley, R.R. and Sons Company |first = |year = 1915 |title = Rules for Compositors |publisher = R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company| location = |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gUU5AAAAMAAJ |isbn = |ref = none}} * {{cite book |last = Lakeside Press |first = |year = 1913 |title = The School for Apprentices of the Lakeside Press |publisher = R.R. Donnelley & Sons Company| location = |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=znJBAQAAMAAJ |isbn = |ref = harv}} * {{cite book| url = http://century.lib.uchicago.edu/images/century0028.pdf |title = The Lakeside Press | place = Chicago | publisher = R.R. {{Infobox person | name = Roberta L. Millstein | image = Roberta_Millstein_Profile.png | image_size =200px | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|birth date†}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = | alma_mater = University of Minnesota | occupation = Professor | known_for = Philosophy of science, history and philosophy of biology, environmental ethics }}
'''Roberta L. Millstein''' is Professor of [[Philosophy]] at the [[University of California, Davis]],<ref name=autogenerated2>[http://philosophy.ucdavis.edu/people/faculty Faculty — Philosophy Department<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://philosophy.ucdavis.edu/people/rlmillst Roberta L. Millstein — Philosophy Department<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=autogenerated3>[http://www.RLM.net Roberta L. Millstein<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> with affiliations in the Science and Technology Studies Program<ref>[http://sts.ucdavis.edu/humans Humans — STS<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and the John Muir Institute for the Environment.<ref>[http://johnmuir.ucdavis.edu/faculty-experts People — John Muir Institute of the Environment<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She is the Senior Co-Chair of the Philosophy of Science Association’s Women's Caucus and an Editor of the peer-reviewed online open-access journal [http://www.philosophyandtheoryinbiology.org/ Philosophy & Theory in Biology].<ref>[http://womenscaucus.philsci.org/ Women's Caucus Home<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Millstein’s primary research is in the history and [[philosophy of biology]] and [[environmental ethics]].<ref name=autogenerated3 /> Millstein’s work on the concepts of [[natural selection]] and random [[genetic drift]] is widely cited.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=X-BgRNIAAAAJ&hl=en Roberta L. Millstein - Google Scholar Citations<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Education and career== Millstein earned her A.B. in [[Philosophy]] and [[Computer Science]] from [[Dartmouth College]] in 1988 and her M.A. and Ph.D. in Philosophy (with a minor in the History of Science and Technology) from the [[University of Minnesota|University of Minnesota, Twin Cities]] in 1997.<ref name=autogenerated4>[https://home.comcast.net/~rmillstein1/cv.html Roberta Millstein's CV<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Millstein taught in the Philosophy Department at California State University, East Bay from 1997-2006, serving as Interim Chair in 2005-6, and she was a Visiting Associate Professor in the Department of History and Philosophy of Science at the University of Pittsburgh in 2005.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> Now Millstein teaches at the University of California, Davis, where she has been since 2006.<ref name=autogenerated2 />
While in graduate school, Millstein studied under [[John Beatty (philosopher)|John Beatty]] and C. Kenneth Waters.<ref name=autogenerated4 /> She has co-authored with [[Michael R. Dietrich]] and Robert A. Skipper, Jr.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
==Research Areas== Millstein is best known for her claim that within [[Evolution|evolutionary theory]], [[natural selection]] can be distinguished from [[Genetic drift|random genetic drift]] if both are properly understood as causal processes rather than outcomes.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{ISBN|0199596271}}</ref><ref>{{ISBN|0226668371}}</ref><ref>DOI 10.1007/s10539-004-1070-9</ref><ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/population-genetics Population Genetics (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> She is also known for the claim that natural selection is a population-level causal process <ref name=autogenerated1 /><ref>[http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/fitness Fitness (Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy)<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>DOI 10.1007/s10539-008-9137-7</ref> but (in a paper co-authored with Robert A. Skipper, Jr.) that current philosophical accounts of mechanisms do not capture it well.<ref>DOI: 10.1086/593075</ref><ref>DOI: 10.1086/660734</ref><ref>{{ISBN|0521858879}}</ref> Her work on the concepts of [[population]] and [[metapopulation]] has been described as exemplifying an approach where biology and philosophy work as equal disciplinary contributors.<ref>http://www.csid.unt.edu/field/NPP2011/Valles.pdf</ref> Her recent co-edited volume ‘’Mechanism and Causality in Biology and Economics’’ (with Hsiang-Ke Chao and Szu-Ting Chen) has been called a “collection of excellent essays” with “novel subject matter”; her own essay in the book is described as a “model of clarity.”<ref>[http://ndpr.nd.edu/news/47038-mechanism-and-causality-in-biology-and-economics Mechanism and Causality in Biology and Economics // Reviews // Notre Dame Philosophical Reviews // University of Notre Dame<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Selected publications== * Millstein, Roberta L. (2002), “Are Random Drift and Natural Selection Conceptually Distinct?” Biology and Philosophy 17(1):33-53. * Skipper, Robert A. and Millstein, Roberta L. (2005) “Thinking about Evolutionary Mechanisms: Natural Selection,” Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences, 36(2): 327-347. Special edition on Mechanisms in Biology, edited by C.F. Craver and L. Darden. * Millstein, Roberta L. (2006), “Natural Selection as a Population-Level Causal Process,” The British Journal for the Philosophy of Science 57(4): 627-653. * Millstein, Roberta L. (2008), “Distinguishing Drift and Selection Empirically: 'The Great Snail Debate' of the 1950s,” Journal of the History of Biology 41: 339-367. * Dietrich, Michael R. and Millstein, Roberta L. (2008), “The Role of Causal Processes in the Neutral and Nearly Neutral Theories,” Philosophy of Science 75 (5): 548-559. * Millstein, Roberta L., Skipper, Robert A., and Dietrich, Michael R. (2009), “(Mis)interpreting Mathematical Models: Drift as a Physical Process,” Philosophy and Theory in Biology 1:e002. * Millstein, Roberta L. (2010), “The Concepts of Population and Metapopulation in Evolutionary Biology and Ecology” in M. A. Bell, D. J. Futuyma, W. F. Eanes, and J. S. Levinton (eds.), Evolution Since Darwin: The First 150 Years, Sunderland, MA: Sinauer, 61-86. * Millstein, Roberta L. (2012), “Darwin's Explanation of Races by Means of Sexual Selection,” Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences 43: 627-633. * Chao, Hsiang-Ke, Chen, Szu-Ting, and Millstein, Roberta L. (Eds.), Mechanism and Causality in Biology and Economics, History, Philosophy and Theory of the Life Sciences, Vol. 3, Springer, 2013.

Master of Arts in Sociology, [[The New School]], 1959 | employer = | notable works = | occupation = | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | opponents = | boards = | spouse =Manfred "Fred" Westheimer (1961–1997; his death) | partner = | children = Miriam, [[Joel Westheimer|Joel]] | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = Signature of Dr. Ruth | website = [http://www.drruth.com/ DrRuth.com] | footnotes = | misc = }} '''Ruth Westheimer''' (born June 4, 1928), better known as '''Dr. Ruth''', is a [[Germany|German]]-born, Jewish immigrant to the United States who became a fixture in late-night television and a major pop culture figure as a [[sex therapy|sex therapist]], media personality, and author. Her media career began in 1980 with the radio show, ''Sexually Speaking'', which continued until 1990. She also hosted at least five television shows on the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] and other [[cable television]] from 1984 to 1993. She is also the author of approximately 40 [[book]]s on a variety of topics about [[sex]] and [[sexuality]]. ==Early life and education== Westheimer was born Karola Ruth Siegel on June 4, 1928, in [[Wiesenfeld (Karlstadt)|Wiesenfeld]] (near [[Karlstadt am Main]]), [[Weimar Republic|Germany]], the only child of [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jews]] Irma (née Hanauer), a housekeeper and Julius Siegel, a notions wholesaler and son of the family for whom Irma worked.{{cite news|url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/westheimer-ruth|title=Ruth Westheimer|publisher=JWA.org|date=March 1, 2009 |accessdate=December 18, 2016}} She was given an early grounding in [[Judaism]] by her father, who took her regularly to the synagogue in [[Frankfurt]], where they lived. In January 1939, she was sent to an orphanage in [[Switzerland]] by her mother and grandmother as part of the ''[[Kindertransport]]'' after her father had been taken by the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]].{{cite web|title=German-American Corner: Ruth Westheimer|url=http://www.germanheritage.com/biographies/mtoz/westheimer.html|website=www.germanheritage.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}}Dullea, Georgia. "[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE5D9103FF935A15753C1A961948260 Therapist to Therapist: Analyzing Dr. Ruth]". ''[[The New York Times]]''. October 26, 1987. She stopped receiving her parents' letters in September 1941. In 1945, Westheimer learned that her parents had been killed in [[the Holocaust]], possibly at the [[Auschwitz concentration camp]].{{cite news|last1=Flax|first1=Peter|last2=Baum|first2=Gary|last3=Roxborough|first3=Scott|last4=Guthrie|first4=Marisa|last5=Lewis|first5=Andy|title=Hollywood's Last Survivors of the Holocaust share their stories|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/holocaust-survivors/dr_ruth_westheimer/|accessdate=December 16, 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=December 16, 2015}} Westheimer decided to emigrate to British-controlled [[Mandatory Palestine]]. There, at 17, she "first had sexual intercourse on a starry night, in a haystack, without contraception." She later told ''[[The New York Times]]'' that "I am not happy about that, but I know much better now and so does everyone who listens to my radio program." Westheimer joined the [[Haganah]] in [[Jerusalem]]. Because of her diminutive height of {{height|ft=4|in=7|abbr=MOS}}, she was trained as a [[Reconnaissance|scout]] and [[sniper]].[http://www.snopes.com/medical/doctor/drruth.asp Urban Legends Reference Pages: Dr. Ruth Was a Sniper] by Barbara Mikkelson, March 1, 2007, Retrieved March 2, 2007. Of this experience, she said, "I never killed anybody, but I know how to throw hand grenades and shoot."{{cite news|last1=Jayson|first1=Sharon|title=Dr. Ruth, pushing age 85, still talking about sex.|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2013/05/15/dr-ruth-westheimer-sex/2162073/|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''USA Today''|date=May 15, 2013}} Westheimer was seriously wounded in action by an exploding [[Shell (projectile)|shell]] during the [[Israeli War of Independence]] in 1948, and it was several months before she was able to walk again.Foreman, Tom (June 11, 2003). [http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/06/0611_030611_drruth_2.html Dr. Ruth: Sex Sage and Ex-Sniper on Global Sexuality]. ''National Geographic''. In 1950, Westheimer moved to France, where she studied and then taught psychology at the [[University of Paris]]. In 1956, she [[Immigration to the United States|immigrated to the United States]], settling in [[Washington Heights, Manhattan]]."Morris, Bob. "[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9802E5D71439F932A15751C1A963958260 At Home With: Dr. Ruth Westheimer; The Bible as Sex Manual?]". ''[[The New York Times]]''. December 21, 1995."[https://archive.org/details/openmind_ep1496 America's Significant Other: Dr. Ruth (1991)]" ''OpenMind'' 1991. Westheimer earned an [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] degree in [[sociology]] from [[The New School]] in 1959{{cite web|url=http://www.drruth.com/content/view/42/27/|title=All About Dr. Ruth|author=Administrator|work=drruth.com}} and an [[Doctor of Education|Ed.D.]] degree from [[Teachers College, Columbia University]] in 1970.{{cite news| author =Joanne Kaufman| title =Dr. Ruth Westheimer: Her Bedrooms Are Off Limits| quote ="I wanted it badly because of the view," said the radio and television sex therapist and author who's known simply as Dr. Ruth (the honorific comes courtesy of her Ph.D. in education).| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =November 29, 2013| url =https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/01/realestate/dr-ruth-westheimer-her-bedrooms-are-off-limits.html| accessdate =July 30, 2015}} Westheimer became a [[Citizenship of the United States|naturalized U.S. citizen]] in 1965.{{cite news|last1=Katz|first1=Mallory M.|title=10 Women Immigrants Who Changed Art, Thought, and Politics in the U.S.|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/10-women-immigrants-who-changed-art-thought-and-politics_us_58d08b72e4b0e0d348b3473f|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''Huffington Post''|date=March 20, 2017}} She regained her [[German nationality law|German citizenship]] in 2012 through the [[German Citizenship Project]] that enabled descendants of Germans deprived of their citizenship during the [[Third Reich]] to reclaim their citizenship without losing the citizenship of their home country.{{cite news|title=Descendants of Holocaust Victims Reclaim German Citizenship |url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/04/16/11230508-descendants-of-holocaust-victims-reclaim-german-citizenship?lite|accessdate=December 31, 2012|publisher=''NBC News''|date=April 16, 2012}} ==Early career== After receiving her Ed.D., she briefly worked for [[Planned Parenthood]] and this experience encouraged her to continue studying [[human sexuality]]. She went on to work as a [[postdoctoral researcher]] for [[Helen Singer Kaplan]] at [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]]. She continued to work there as an Adjunct Associate Professor for five years. She also taught at [[Lehman College]], [[Brooklyn College]], [[Adelphi University]], [[Columbia University]] and [[West Point]].{{cite web|title=All About Dr. Ruth.|url=http://www.drruth.com/content/view/42/27|website=DrRuth.com|accessdate=March 24, 2017}} ==Media career== Dr. Ruth's media career began in 1980 when her radio show, ''Sexually Speaking'', debuted on [[WQHT#WYNY|WYNY-FM]] in New York City.{{cite book|last1=Sterling|first1=Christopher H.|title=Biographical Encyclopedia of American Radio|date=2011|publisher=Routledge|location=New York City|isbn=978-0-415-99549-8|page=423|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mdQq-663faAC&pg=PA423&lpg=PA423&dq=dr.+ruth+WYNY+1980#v=onepage&q=dr.%20ruth%20WYNY%201980&f=false|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} She was offered this opportunity after she gave a lecture to New York broadcasters about the need for [[sex education]] programming to help deal with issues of [[contraception]] and unwanted pregnancies. Betty Elam, the community affairs manager at WYNY, was impressed with her talk and offered Westheimer [[United States dollar|$]]25 per week to make ''Sexually Speaking'', which started as a 15-minute show airing every Sunday at midnight.{{cite web|last1=Staff Writers|title=Dr. Ruth Westheimer Biography.|url=http://www.biography.com/people/dr-ruth-westheimer-9542073|website=Biography.com|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} By 1983, her show was the top-rated radio show in the area, and in 1984, [[NBC Radio]] began [[Broadcast syndication|syndicating]] it nationwide, renaming the show to the ''Dr. Ruth Show''. She went on to produce her radio show until 1990.{{cite web|title=Interview with Dr. Ruth Westheimer.|url=http://www.makers.com/dr-ruth-westheimer|website=www.makers.com|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} Described as the, "[[Sister Wendy]] of Sexuality", Dr. Ruth helped to revolutionize talk about sex and sexuality on radio and television, and she was noted for having, "an accent only a psychologist could love."{{cite news|last1=Barron|first1=James|title=ART/ARCHITECTURE; Some Things Never Age. Just Ask Dr. Ruth.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/13/arts/art-architecture-some-things-never-age-just-ask-dr-ruth.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''New York Times''|date=December 13, 1998}} She became known for being candid and funny, but respectful, and for her tag phrase, "Get some".{{cite news|last1=Kahn|first1=Joseph P.|title=A sex expert for the ages.|url=http://archive.boston.com/lifestyle/articles/2011/04/07/dr_ruth_westheimer_discusses_her_career_as_a_sex_therapist/|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''Boston Globe''|date=April 7, 2011}}{{cite news|last1=Griset|first1=Rich|title=Moment of Ruth.|url=http://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/moment-of-ruth/Content?oid=2121380|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''Style Weekly''|date=September 23, 2014}} One journalist described her unique voice as, "a cross between [[Henry Kissinger]] and [[Minnie Mouse]]."{{cite news|last1=Schuessler|first1=Jennifer|title=Audiences Can Now Analyze Dr. Ruth.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/24/theater/new-play-about-dr-ruth-westheimer.html|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''New York Times''|date=June 21, 2012}} In 1984, Westheimer began hosting several television programs on the [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] TV network and one in syndication. Her first show was ''Good Sex! With Dr. Ruth Westheimer'', airing for a half hour at 10 pm on weeknights. This show was expanded in 1985 to a full hour and its name was changed to ''The Dr. Ruth Show''. In 1987, she began a separate half hour syndicated series on many broadcast stations called, ''Ask Dr. Ruth'', which was co-hosted by Larry Angelo. Dr. Ruth returned to the Lifetime network in 1988 with ''The All New Dr. Ruth Show'', which was followed in 1989 by two teen advice shows called ''What's Up, Dr. Ruth?'' and a call-in show, ''You're on the Air with Dr. Ruth'' in 1990.{{cite book|last1=Brooks|first1=Tim|last2=Marsh|first2=Earle F.|title=The Complete Directory to Prime Time Network and Cable TV Shows, 1946-Present|date=2007|publisher=Ballentine Books|location=New York City|isbn=978-0-345-49773-4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=w8KztFy6QYwC&pg=PA373&dq=dr.+ruth+lifetime+tv+show#v=onepage&q=dr.%20ruth%20lifetime%20tv%20show&f=false|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} In 1993, Westheimer and Israeli TV host, Arad Nir, hosted a talk show in Hebrew, titled ''Min Tochnit'', on the newly opened Israeli Channel 2. The show was similar to her US ''Sexually Speaking'' show. The name of the show, ''Min Tochnit'', is a play of words: literally "Kind of a program", but "Min" (מין) in Hebrew also means "[[sex]]" and "[[gender]]".{{cite web|title=Min Tochnit|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0332951/|website=IMDB|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} During the 1980s, "Dr. Ruth", became a household name and she made guest appearances on several [[network television]] shows, including ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson]]'' and ''[[Late Night with David Letterman]]''.{{cite book|last1=Wolf|first1=Michelle Andrea|last2=Kielwasser, Aldred P.|title=Gay People, Sex, and the Media|date=1991|publisher=The Haworth Press|location=New York City; London|isbn=0-86656-936-7|page=142|url=https://books.google.com/?id=Y_Hd0F2J7LEC&pg=PA142&lpg=PA142&dq=david+letterman+westheimer#v=onepage&q=david%20letterman%20westheimer&f=false}} She also made frequent appearances on the syndicated revival of ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' that ran from 1986 to 1989. In the 1990s, Westheimer appeared as herself in [[Quantum Leap (season 5)|episode 89]] of ''[[Quantum Leap (TV series)|Quantum Leap]]'', the episode title being "Dr. Ruth". She appeared on [[Tom Chapin]]'s album ''This Pretty Planet'', in the song "Two Kinds of Seagulls", in which she and Chapin sing of various animals that reproduce sexually. "It takes two to tingle", says the song. Dr. Ruth also appeared in several commercial advertisements, including a 1994 [[Honda Prelude]] ad, and an ad for [[Clairol]] [[Herbal Essences]] [[shampoo]] and body wash.{{cite journal|title=Dr. Ruth pilots Prelude ad.|journal=''Advertising Age''|date=October 1994|volume=65|issue=42|page=45|url=http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/9410190935/dr-ruth-pilots-prelude-ad|accessdate=March 25, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Clairol Herbal Essences - Dr. Ruth (1990)|url=http://www.retrojunk.com/commercial/show/1653/clairol-herbal-essences-dr-ruth|website=www.retrojunk.com|accessdate=March 25, 2017}} Between 2001 and 2007, Westheimer made regular appearances on the [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] Television children's show ''[[Between the Lions]]'' as "Dr. Ruth Wordheimer" in a parody of her therapist role, in which she helps anxious readers and spellers overcome their fear of long words. In the January 2009, the 55th anniversary issue of ''[[Playboy]]'' magazine includes Westheimer as #13 in the list of the 55 most important people in sex from the past 55 years.{{cite news|last1=Geller|first1=Adam|title=At 84, legendary sex therapist Dr. Ruth still has lots to talk about.|url=http://www.masslive.com/living/index.ssf/2012/07/post_134.html|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''Masslive''|date=July 25, 2012}} In October 2013, the play, ''Becoming Dr. Ruth'' opened Off Broadway. Actress [[Debra Jo Rupp]] played the role of Dr. Ruth. The play showcased the sex therapist's life from fleeing the Nazis in the Kindertransport and joining the [[Haganah]] in Jerusalem as a scout and sniper, to her struggles to succeed as a single mother coming to America.{{cite news|last1=Rooney|first1=David|title=The Sex Therapist's Story, From Calamity to Cliché.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/30/theater/reviews/becoming-dr-ruth-with-debra-jo-rupp-at-westside-theater.html|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''New York Times''|date=October 29, 2013}} [[Eileen DeSandre]] played Dr. Ruth in the Virginia Repertory Theatre production of ''Becoming Dr. Ruth''.{{cite news|last1=Wren|first1=Celia|title=Virginia Rep production brings Dr. Ruth, and her story, to Richmond.|url=http://www.richmond.com/entertainment/theater/virginia-rep-production-brings-dr-ruth-and-her-story-to/article_403aceea-1446-54f6-8f37-5ce2a6bbafb7.html|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''Richmond Times-Dispatch''|date=September 13, 2014}} Westheimer has delivered [[commencement speech]]es at the [[Hebrew Union College]] [[seminary]], [[Lehman College]] of the [[City University of New York]], and, in 2004, at [[Trinity College (Connecticut)|Trinity College]], where she has been awarded [[honorary degree]]s.{{cite news|last1=Gordon|first1=Jane|title=WORTH NOTING; Calling Dr. Ruth (To Speak at Trinity).|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/05/09/nyregion/worth-noting-calling-dr-ruth-to-speak-at-trinity.html?_r=0|accessdate=March 25, 2017|publisher=''New York Times''|date=May 9, 2004}} She also taught courses and seminars at [[Princeton University|Princeton]] and [[Yale University|Yale]], and was the guest speaker at the [[Bronx High School of Science]] in New York in commemoration of [[Yom HaShoah]] 2008. Westheimer spoke about her life story and the audience of 500 sang "[[Happy Birthday to You|Happy Birthday]]" in honor of her 80th birthday. At the ceremony she received an honorary Bronx High School of Science diploma. In 2002, she received the [[Leo Baeck Institute|Leo Baeck Medal]] for her humanitarian work promoting tolerance and [[social justice]]. ==Personal life== [[File:Dr. Ruth Westheimer 2009.jpg|thumb|Dr. Ruth Westheimer in 2009.]] Westheimer has been married three times. She said that each of her marriages played an important role in her relationship advice, but after two divorces, it was her third marriage, to Manfred Westheimer, that was the "real marriage". This lasted until his death in 1997. She has two children, Miriam and [[Joel Westheimer|Joel]], and four grandchildren. In December 2014, Westheimer was a guest at an Orthodox Jewish wedding in the Bronx, NY. The groom, Rabbi Benjamin Goldschmidt, is the great-grandson of the woman who had helped rescue Westheimer from Nazi Germany.{{cite news|last1=Brawarsky|first1=Sandee|title=Vows Taking Their Sweet Time|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/21/fashion/weddings/taking-their-time.html|accessdate=December 27, 2014|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=December 21, 2014}} She still lives in the "cluttered three-bedroom apartment in Washington Heights where she raised her two children and became famous, in that order."{{cite news| author =Joanne Kaufman| title =Dr. Ruth Westheimer: Her Bedrooms Are Off Limits| quote =| newspaper =[[The New York Times]]| date =November 29, 2013| url =https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/01/realestate/dr-ruth-westheimer-her-bedrooms-are-off-limits.html| accessdate =July 30, 2015}}{{cite news| author =Vanita Salisbury| title =Dr. Ruth Has Seen the Play About Her Life More Than Fifteen Times| quote =| newspaper =[[New York (magazine)|New York]]| date = November 27, 2013| url =http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2013/11/dr-ruth-21-questions.html| accessdate = July 30, 2015}} Because of the two [[synagogue]]s she belongs to, the [[Jewish Community Center|YMHA]] she was president of for three years, and a "still sizable community of German Jewish World War II refugees", she remains in the neighborhood. '''School fundraising''' or '''school fund raising''' is the practice of raising money to support educational enrichment programs by schools or school groups mostly known from the [[United States]] (e.g., parent-teacher organizations, booster clubs, etc.). One of the most prevalent practices in the United States is product fundraising. Schools and other non-profits raise $1.7 billion each year by selling popular consumer items.<ref>[http://www.afrds.org/news_4_18_06.html Association of Fund-Raising Distributors and Suppliers (AFRDS)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603121526/http://www.afrds.org/news_4_18_06.html |date=June 3, 2011 }}</ref> Eight out of 10 Americans support these types of programs.<ref>[http://www.afrds.org/news_20070509_01.html Association of Fund-Raising Distributors and Suppliers (AFRDS)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603121648/http://www.afrds.org/news_20070509_01.html |date=June 3, 2011 }}</ref> In addition, schools and school groups such as their [[Parent Teacher Organization]] and [[Parent Teacher Association]] find many creative ways to raise funds—from bake sales, dinner events, auctions and school carnivals to more aggressive advertising, affinity programs, grant writing and straight forward donation requests.
== Product fundraisers == Product fundraising has its origins in the early 20th century.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} The practice typically involves the purchase and re-sale of popular consumer products by a non-profit group whereupon the group sponsoring the sale keeps a portion of the gross sales. Products can be purchased in bulk and paid for in advance by the organization, then re-sold to supporters. Products may also be ordered using a catalog, order forms and other methods. Supporters pay for the product when the order is placed or upon final delivery. Under some product fundraising models, the school or non-profit organization is required to pay for a fixed number of products in advance.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pedersen|first1=Jason|title=School Fundraising|url=http://www.schoolawards.net/school-fundraising/|publisher=SchoolAwards.net|accessdate=19 March 2016}}</ref>
There are three types of product fundraisers that schools use to generate revenue. (1) Pre-sales Fundraising, (2) Product In-Hand Fundraising, (3) Online Fundraising, with online fundraising rising in popularity over the course of the past decade.
As of 2010, there are over a thousand fundraising companies in the United States offering their products and services to schools and their associated nonprofit parent teacher groups.<ref>[http://www.fundraising-ideas.org/ Fundraising Companies Directory]</ref> In the past year, many changes have occurred in the school fundraising industry. A few online fundraising companies, like [[Piggybackr]], are now using [[social media]] web apps, such as Facebook and Twitter, to make online fundraising easier for schools and the parents and students who promote them. Additionally, Fundraising Software is also now available allowing a school to have their own platform that makes it easy to engage students, parents, faculty, donors, and alumni with compelling communication campaigns.
==Self-organized school fundraisers ==
Other school fundraisers that generate substantial revenue for schools include [[auction]]s and [[raffle]]s. With these types of fundraising activities, the school requests donations from local restaurants and businesses in their area, that are then offered at the event. In the case of an auction, people are allowed to bid on the dinner, limousine ride, or whatever was donated by the local businesses in the community. In the case of a raffle, people purchase raffle tickets that are then later picked randomly from a container. Often the donations are solicited by parents acting on behalf of the school, who make phone calls, write letters, or know of other parents who work for companies who may be willing to donate.<ref>[http://www.fundraising-ideas.org/DIY/ Fundraising Ideas & Products Center - Do It Yourself Fundraising]</ref>
==Scrip fundraising== Scrip fundraising offers an alternative to fundraisers that rely on selling products or raffle tickets. The scrip fundraising concept was pioneered by St. Vincent DePaul Parish in Petaluma CA in 1988, and quickly grew to a powerful fundraising method for schools across the US.<ref>[http://www.pressdemocrat.com/news/2835321-181/following-the-scriphow-a-sr-based?page=3 Santa Rosa Press Democrat, "Following the Scrip: How an SR-Based Group Revolutionized the Hottest Method of School Fundraising"]</ref>
With scrip fundraising, retailers offer gift cards (“scrip”, or “substitute money”) at a discount to non-profit organizations. The non-profit organizations then sell the gift cards to member families at full face value. The families redeem the gift cards at full face value, and the discount or rebate is retained by the non-profit organization as revenue.<ref>[http://www.ptotoday.com/pto-today-articles/article/1031-managing-your-scrip-program PTO Today, "Managing Your Scrip Program"]</ref>
Great Lakes Scrip Center reports that more than 17,000 non-profit organizations have raised more than $500 million with scrip fundraising.<ref>[https://www.shopwithscrip.com/Support/about-us/our-company GLSC: About our Company]</ref> Scrip fundraising differs from other school fundraising programs because there is no selling. Families do their normal household shopping at scrip retailers with scrip gift cards. A family that regularly does their shopping with scrip gift cards can easily raise $500 to $1000 or more per year. Participating schools use these funds for field trips, scholarships, tuition assistance or fee reductions.
One persistent and basic question has been whether or not any portion of the funds that are raised through a scrip program and applied to a family’s tuition account should be considered taxable income to the parent who purchases the scrip. According to Great Lakes Scrip Center, scrip is a reduction in purchase price from the face value, and is in effect a rebate from the retailer, and as such is not considered gross income.<ref>[https://www.shopwithscrip.com/N2Upload/tax_info/TaxMemo.pdf Overview of Scrip Tax Issues, Private Letter Ruling-118535-09 -]</ref><ref>[https://www.shopwithscrip.com/Support/scrip-program-management/are-there-scrip-tax-implications-for-my-non-profit-organization "Are there scrip tax implications for my non-profit organization?"]</ref>
==Economic pressures == Some parents and schools are now having to resort to extensive fundraising, including in one case having to raise $300,000 in six months to close budget gaps in order to keep Cordova Lane Elementary School in [[Sacramento]], [[California]] open.<ref>[http://www.sacbee.com/2010/02/10/2525715/as-school-funding-falls-fundraisers.html Sacramento Bee, Oct 3, 2010]</ref>
Additionally, general economic hardships can cause school fundraisers to earn less, as volunteer time is spread thin with more families requiring dual incomes. A survey done by national fundraising association in 2007 determined that on average the most labor-intensive school wide fundraisers, in terms of the number of volunteers needed is school carnivals, with an average of 59 volunteers needed. Other labor-intensive fundraisers included: auctions (28), "thons" such as walk-a-thons (22), breakfasts or dinners (17) and raffles (17). By contrast the least labor-intensive fundraisers for schools included: product fundraisers (7), direct donations (7), restaurant nights (6) and student portraits (2).<ref>[http://www.fundraising-newsletters.com/product-sales-out-perform-other-school-fundraisers.html Fundraising Newsletter]</ref> Another survey from the same source showed 71% of parents are "concerned and overwhelmed" with having to do more fundraisers.<ref>[http://www.afrds.org/fundraising_logistics.html#3 AFRDS] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100813133943/http://www.afrds.org/fundraising_logistics.html#3 |date=August 13, 2010 }}</ref>
== History == Door-to-door fundraising and in hand product fundraising sales (out side local stores) has been a regular part of societal activities since the early 1970s. However, door-to-door sales came under scrutiny in 1997 following the murder of an 11-year-old New Jersey boy who was killed while fundraising unsupervised in his neighborhood. Due to this fundraisers do not allow kids to go door to door.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/09/nyregion/a-plan-to-ban-door-to-door-sales-by-schoolchildren-is-praised-by-educators.html?partner=rssnyt New York Times, Dec 9, 1997]</ref> Today, most product sales are made to parents, family members, co-workers, friends and close neighbors. The fundraising industry strongly discourages unsupervised door-to-door sales.<ref>[http://www.afrds.org/fundraisingfaq.html#6 AFRDS] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110502062637/http://www.afrds.org/fundraisingfaq.html#6 |date=May 2, 2011 }}</ref>
==See also==

'''Siviløkonom''' (literally "civil economist") is an [[academic degree]] issued within the field of [[business administration]] and a professional title in [[Norway]] (with corresponding titles in [[Denmark]] and [[Sweden]], see below under "See also"), obtained after 3 to 5 years of studies. The title is protected and can only be used by persons having met certain qualifications as directed by the [[Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research]]. It is mainly offered by nine institutions after the completion of a [[Master of Science in Business Administration]].
Master of Science in Business Administration programs entitling the Siviløkonom in Norway are: * [[Oslo and Akershus University College of Applied Sciences]] (HiOA) ([[Oslo]]) * [[Bodø Graduate School of Business]] ([[University of Nordland|UiN]]) ([[Bodø]]) * [[NHH|Norwegian School of Economics]] (NHH) ([[Bergen]]) * [[BI Norwegian Business School]] (BI) ([[Oslo]]) * [[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]] ([[Ås, Akershus|Ås]]) * [[Buskerud University College]] ([[Hønefoss]]) * [[Molde University College]] ([[Molde]]) * [[Trondheim Business School]] ([[Sør-Trøndelag University College|HiST]]) ([[Trondheim]]) * [[University of Agder]] ([[Kristiansand]]) * [[University of Stavanger]] ([[Stavanger]]) * [[University of Tromsø]] ([[Tromsø]])
Additionally, the title can be granted to candidates with foreign education meeting certain criteria, through application to the NHH. Due to changes in the Norwegian educational system, granting of the title based on foreign education will be phased out on 12/31/2008, and can through that date only be granted to persons who started their qualifying education prior to 1/1/2003.
==History== Traditionally the siviløkonom degree was only offered at NHH in [[Bergen]], and was originally a two-year, then three-year program. In 1975 it became a four-year business administration degree at the level equivalent to a [[cand.mag.]] degree. NHH had a monopoly on awarding the degree until 1985 when the Norwegian School of Management BI and the Bodø Graduate School of Business was allowed to offer the degree. After the [[Norwegian higher education quality reform|quality reform]] all institutions of higher education were allowed to issue the title to all master graduates, and the requirements for the degree increased from four to five years of study.
==See also== * [[Civilekonom]] for the corresponding [[Sweden|Swedish]] title * [[Civiløkonom]] for the corresponding [[Denmark|Danish]] title

The '''Southern Association of Colleges and Schools''' ('''SACS''') is one of the [[regional accreditation|six]] regional [[school accreditation|accreditation]] organizations recognized by the [[United States Department of Education]] and the [[Council for Higher Education Accreditation]]. This agency accredits over 13,000 public and private educational institutions ranging from [[preschool]] to college level in the [[Southern United States]]. Its headquarters are in [[North Druid Hills, Georgia]], near [[Decatur, Georgia|Decatur]] and in the [[Atlanta metropolitan area]].<ref>"[http://www2.census.gov/geo/maps/dc10map/GUBlock/st13_ga/place/p1356168_north_druid_hills/DC10BLK_P1356168_001.pdf 2010 CENSUS – CENSUS BLOCK MAP: North Druid Hills CDP, GA]" ([https://www.webcitation.org/6YSToBPzC Archive]). [[U.S. Census Bureau]]. Retrieved on May 12, 2015.</ref><ref>"[http://www.sacscoc.org/ Home]." Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges. Retrieved on May 12, 2015. "© 2014 Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges 1866 Southern Lane, Decatur, GA 30033"</ref>
SACS accredits educational institutions in the states of [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[North Carolina]], [[South Carolina]], [[Alabama]], [[Tennessee]], [[Texas]], and [[Virginia]], as well as schools for US students in [[Mexico]], the [[Caribbean]], [[Central America]], and [[South America]].
There are a number of affiliate organizations within the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools. One affiliate organization is the Southern Association of Community, Junior, and Technical Colleges.
==Commission on Colleges== The SACS Commission on Colleges (SACSCOC) accredits [[universities]] and [[college]]s in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, and Latin America (Extraterritorial).
Every six months, the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges publishes an online report on its accreditation actions, including reaffirmations of accreditation and public sanctions of institutions of higher learning.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sacscoc.org/ |title=Commission on Colleges |accessdate=2009-05-04}}</ref> The reports include specific public sanctions of schools and statements disclosing why those institutions have been placed on sanction.
The Commission on Colleges accredits both public and private institutions of higher education in the United States, including some [[community college]]s as well as four-year institutions. As a [[regional accreditation|regional accreditor]], SACSCOC accreditation extends to all of the educational programs offered at the accredited institution.
Institutions in Latin America accredited by SACSCOC include the Mexican universities of [[Fundación Universidad de las Américas, Puebla]]; [[Universidad de las Americas, A.C.]]; [[Universidad de Monterrey]]; [[Tecnológico de Monterrey]]; [[INCAE|Instituto Centroamericano de Administración de Empresas]] (INCAE or the Central American Institute of Business Administration) in Costa Rica and Nicaragua; and Keiser University Latin American Campus in Nicaragua. The SACSCOC has also accredited the [[American University in Dubai]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacscoc.org/pdf/webmemlist.pdf |title=Member, Candidate and Applicant List |publisher=Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges |date=January 2013 |accessdate=March 24, 2013}}</ref>
==Council on Accreditation and School Improvement== SACS CASI accredits over 13,000 [[primary school|primary]], [[middle school|middle]], and [[secondary school]]s, as well as [[school systems]] located in the SACS region. In 2006, [[AdvancED]] was established with the unification of SACS CASI, [[North Central Association of Colleges and Schools|NCA CASI]], and NSSE creating the world's largest education community.<ref>{{cite web|title=AdvancED|url=http://www.advanc-ed.org/about-us}}</ref> Today, SACS CASI acts as an accreditation division of AdvancED.
==See also== *[[List of recognized accreditation associations of higher learning]]

'''Tamar Sanikidze''' ({{lang-ka|თამარ სანიკიძე}}) (born 30 August 1978 in [[Tbilisi]]) was the [[Ministry of Education and Science (Georgia)|Minister of Education and Science of Georgia]] until the announcement of her resignation on June 3rd of 2016..<ref>Ministry of Education and Science of Georgia,[http://www.mes.gov.ge/content.php?id=8&lang=eng| Tamar Sanikidze]</ref>
==Education== Tamar attended [[Tbilisi State University]] from 1995 to 1998, earning a bachelor's degree, specializing in English literature. She received a master's degree at the Georgian Institute of Public Affairs in 2000, and participated in the [[University of Glasgow]] Distance Learning Program from 2003 to 2007.
==Posts held== Tamar was a leading specialist for the Naval Department of the Ministry of Transport from March 1998 to July 1999.
She has held multiple positions in the Georgian Urban Institute. From 2006 to 2009, she was the financial manager for the institute, and a purchasing manager from July 2005 to May 2006. In 2005, she was made the coordinator of the institute's Resource Management Program. She was also a financial manager for the Institute of Public Affairs from 2009 to October 2012. She was appointed as Minister of Education and Science the same year, replacing Deputy [[Giorgi Margvelashvili]], the current [[President of Georgia]].<ref>Government of Georgia,[http://www.government.gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=geo&sec_id=27&info_id=622| Tamar Sanikidze]</ref>
From May 2001 to September 2003, she was the Deputy Financial Director of the Black & Veach (UK) LTD in the Tbilisi Financial Project. From November 2000 to May 2001, she was assigned to assess construction works for the same company.<ref>NetGazeti,[http://www.netgazeti.ge/GE/105/News/21642/ Biography of the Minister of Education and Science]</ref>
==Criticisms==
Sanikidze's tenure as Education Minister came under repeated criticism for the low number of teachers who passed their professional exams.<ref>Democracy and Freedom Watch,[http://dfwatch.net/17-of-teachers-pass-professional-exams-up-from-4-in-2015-40810]</ref>
